sections.title: Electronic Configuration
sections.content:
**Electronic Configuration** describes how electrons are arranged in atoms.

**Key Principles:**
1. **Aufbau Principle:** Electrons fill orbitals from lowest to highest energy
2. **Pauli Exclusion Principle:** Maximum 2 electrons per orbital (opposite spins)
3. **Hund's Rule:** Electrons occupy orbitals singly before pairing

**Orbital Energy Order:**
1s < 2s < 2p < 3s < 3p < 4s < 3d < 4p < 5s < 4d < 5p

**Singapore Example:**
Semiconductor manufacturing in Singapore (GlobalFoundries) relies on understanding electronic configuration of silicon. Silicon's configuration (1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s² 3p²) makes it ideal for electronics—four valence electrons allow controllable conductivity.

**Writing Configurations:**
- Nitrogen (Z=7): 1s² 2s² 2p³
- Iron (Z=26): [Ar] 4s² 3d⁶
- Copper (Z=29): [Ar] 4s¹ 3d¹⁰ (exception for stability)

**Ions:**
- Na⁺: [Ne] (loses 3s¹)
- Cl⁻: [Ar] (gains electron to 3p⁶)
- Fe²⁺: [Ar] 3d⁶ (loses 4s² electrons first)

**Note:** Transition metals lose 4s electrons before 3d when forming ions.

sections.title: Ionization Energy
sections.content:
**Ionization Energy (IE)** is energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of gaseous atoms.

**First Ionization Energy:**
M(g) → M⁺(g) + e⁻     ΔH = IE₁

**Factors Affecting IE:**
1. **Nuclear Charge:** Higher Z → stronger attraction → higher IE
2. **Distance:** Larger radius → weaker attraction → lower IE
3. **Shielding:** More inner electrons → reduced attraction → lower IE

**Periodic Trends:**
- **Across Period:** Generally increases (higher Z, similar shielding)
- **Down Group:** Decreases (larger radius, more shielding)

**Exceptions:**
- Group 13 < Group 2 (Al < Mg): p orbital higher energy than s
- Group 16 < Group 15 (S < P): paired electron in p orbital easier to remove

**Successive Ionization Energies:**
IE₁ < IE₂ < IE₃ < ... (removing from increasingly positive ion)

**Large Jumps Indicate:** Removal from new inner shell
Example: Magnesium
- IE₁ = 738 kJ/mol (3s¹)
- IE₂ = 1451 kJ/mol (3s²)
- IE₃ = 7733 kJ/mol (HUGE—from 2p⁶)

**Singapore Application:**
Mass spectrometry at Singapore's pharmaceutical R&D (Novartis) uses ionization. Understanding IE predicts fragmentation patterns crucial for drug analysis.

sections.title: Periodic Trends
sections.content:
**Periodic Trends** show systematic variation of atomic properties.

**1. Atomic Radius**
- **Across Period:** Decreases (higher Z, same shell)
- **Down Group:** Increases (additional shells)

**2. Ionic Radius**
- **Cations:** Smaller than parent (electron loss, less repulsion)
- **Anions:** Larger than parent (electron gain, more repulsion)
- **Isoelectronic Series:** More protons → smaller
  Example: O²⁻ (140 pm) > F⁻ (133 pm) > Na⁺ (98 pm) > Mg²⁺ (79 pm)

**3. Electronegativity (Pauling Scale)**
- **Across Period:** Increases
- **Down Group:** Decreases
- **Most electronegative:** F (4.0) > O (3.5) > Cl (3.0) > N (3.0)

**4. Electron Affinity**
- Energy change when electron added to gaseous atom
- Generally more negative across period (more favorable)

**5. Metallic Character**
- **Across Period:** Decreases (metals → metalloids → non-metals)
- **Down Group:** Increases (easier electron loss)

**Singapore Context:**
NEWater's reverse osmosis membranes exploit ionic radii differences:
- Smaller ions (Na⁺) pass through more easily than larger ions (Ca²⁺)
- Understanding trends optimizes water treatment efficiency

Electronics industry uses electronegativity to predict:
- Compound formation in semiconductor doping
- Bond polarity in materials science

sections.title: Types of Chemical Bonds
sections.content:
**Chemical Bonds** form when atoms achieve stable electron configurations.

**1. Ionic Bonding**
- **Formation:** Electron transfer (metal → non-metal)
- **Example:** Na⁺Cl⁻
- **Properties:**
  - High mp/bp (strong electrostatic forces)
  - Conduct when molten/aqueous (mobile ions)
  - Brittle (like-charge repulsion when layers shift)
  - Soluble in polar solvents

**Lattice Energy:** Energy released forming ionic lattice from gaseous ions
- Higher charge → stronger attraction → higher lattice energy
- Smaller ions → closer approach → higher lattice energy

**2. Covalent Bonding**
- **Formation:** Electron sharing (non-metal + non-metal)
- **Types:**
  - **Single:** C-C (2 electrons shared)
  - **Double:** C=O (4 electrons)
  - **Triple:** N≡N (6 electrons)

**Simple Molecular:**
- Weak intermolecular forces
- Low mp/bp
- Don't conduct electricity
- Examples: H₂O, CO₂, NH₃

**Giant Covalent (Network):**
- Strong covalent bonds throughout
- Very high mp/bp
- Examples: Diamond (C), Silicon dioxide (SiO₂)

**3. Metallic Bonding**
- **Structure:** Delocalized electrons in "sea" around metal cations
- **Properties:**
  - Electrical conductivity (mobile electrons)
  - Thermal conductivity
  - Malleable/ductile (layers slide)
  - Lustrous (electrons reflect light)

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Desalination:** Tuas plant separates ionic NaCl
- **Petrochemicals:** Jurong Island processes covalent hydrocarbons
- **Electronics:** Metallic solder (Sn-Pb alloy) in circuit boards
- **Construction:** Steel (metallic Fe) in MRT structures

sections.title: VSEPR Theory
sections.content:
**VSEPR Theory** (Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion) predicts 3D molecular shapes.

**Key Principle:** Electron pairs (bonding + lone) repel to maximize separation.

**Common Shapes:**

**2 Regions:**
- **Linear** (180°): CO₂, BeCl₂

**3 Regions:**
- **Trigonal Planar** (120°): BF₃, AlCl₃
- **Bent** (~120°): SO₂ (1 lone pair)

**4 Regions:**
- **Tetrahedral** (109.5°): CH₄, NH₄⁺
- **Trigonal Pyramidal** (~107°): NH₃ (1 lone pair)
- **Bent** (~104.5°): H₂O (2 lone pairs)

**5 Regions:**
- **Trigonal Bipyramidal** (90°, 120°): PCl₅
- **Seesaw:** SF₄ (1 lone pair)

**6 Regions:**
- **Octahedral** (90°): SF₆
- **Square Pyramidal:** BrF₅ (1 lone pair)
- **Square Planar:** XeF₄ (2 lone pairs)

**Repulsion Order:**
LP-LP > LP-BP > BP-BP

**Bond Angle Trends:**
- CH₄: 109.5° (perfect tetrahedral)
- NH₃: 107° (lone pair compression)
- H₂O: 104.5° (2 lone pairs compress more)

**Polarity:**
- **Polar:** Asymmetric shape + polar bonds (H₂O, NH₃, HCl)
- **Non-polar:** Symmetric shape cancels dipoles (CO₂, CH₄, BF₃)

**Singapore Example:**
Pharmaceutical design at Singapore biopharma companies:
- Drug molecule shape determines receptor binding
- Water's bent shape → polarity → excellent biological solvent
- NEWater plant efficiency depends on H₂O polarity

sections.title: Intermolecular Forces
sections.content:
**Intermolecular Forces (IMF)** are attractions between molecules (weaker than chemical bonds).

**1. Van der Waals (Dispersion/London Forces)**
- **Cause:** Temporary dipoles from electron movement
- **Strength:** ∝ molecular size (more electrons)
- **All molecules** have dispersion forces
- **Example:** Noble gases, alkanes
- **Trend:** He < Ne < Ar < Kr (increasing bp)

**2. Permanent Dipole-Dipole**
- **Requirement:** Polar molecules
- **Strength:** Stronger than dispersion alone
- **Example:** HCl (δ⁺H—Clδ⁻)
- Molecules align: δ⁺ near δ⁻

**3. Hydrogen Bonding** (Strongest IMF)
- **Requirements:**
  - H bonded to N, O, or F
  - Lone pair on nearby N, O, or F
- **Examples:**
  - H₂O: bp 100°C (anomalously high)
  - NH₃: bp -33°C (higher than PH₃)
  - HF: bp 20°C (highest of hydrogen halides)

**Effects on Physical Properties:**

**Boiling Point:**
- Stronger IMF → higher bp
- Alkanes: CH₄ (-164°C) < C₂H₆ (-89°C) < C₃H₈ (-42°C)
- Alcohols: Higher bp than alkanes (H-bonding)

**Solubility:**
- **"Like dissolves like"**
- Polar solutes in polar solvents
- Non-polar solutes in non-polar solvents

**Viscosity:**
- Stronger IMF → higher viscosity
- H-bonding increases viscosity

**Ice Density Anomaly:**
- H-bonding creates open structure in ice
- Ice less dense than liquid water
- Allows aquatic life in frozen lakes

**Singapore Applications:**
- **NEWater:** H-bonding makes water excellent solvent for treatment
- **Petrochemicals:** Separating hydrocarbons by bp at Jurong refineries
- **Pharmaceuticals:** Drug design considers IMF for solubility
- **Humidity:** Singapore's high humidity from strong H-bonding in water
- **Air Conditioning:** Refrigerants chosen based on IMF properties

sections.title: Gas Laws
sections.content:
**Gas Laws** describe relationships between P, V, T, and n.

**Individual Gas Laws:**

**Boyle's Law** (T, n constant): P₁V₁ = P₂V₂
- Pressure inversely proportional to volume

**Charles's Law** (P, n constant): V₁/T₁ = V₂/T₂
- Volume directly proportional to temperature (Kelvin)

**Gay-Lussac's Law** (V, n constant): P₁/T₁ = P₂/T₂
- Pressure directly proportional to temperature

**Avogadro's Law** (P, T constant): V/n = constant
- Equal volumes of gases contain equal moles (at same T, P)
- 1 mole any gas = 22.4 L at STP (0°C, 1 atm)

**Ideal Gas Equation:**
PV = nRT
- P = pressure (Pa, atm, kPa)
- V = volume (m³, L, dm³)
- n = amount (mol)
- R = gas constant
  - 8.31 J/(mol·K)
  - 0.0821 L·atm/(mol·K)
  - 8.31 dm³·kPa/(mol·K)
- T = temperature (K only!)

**Combined Gas Law:**
P₁V₁/T₁ = P₂V₂/T₂

**Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures:**
P_total = P₁ + P₂ + P₃ + ...
P_i = χ_i × P_total (χ = mole fraction)

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Scuba Diving:** Sentosa divers—pressure increases with depth
- **Aircraft:** Changi Airport cabin pressurization
- **Industrial Gases:** Air Liquide stores compressed gases
- **Weather:** Meteorological Service balloon expansion

**Example:**
2.0 mol O₂ at 300K, 1.0 atm. Volume?
V = nRT/P = (2.0)(0.0821)(300)/1.0 = 49.3 L

sections.title: Kinetic Molecular Theory
sections.content:
**Kinetic Molecular Theory (KMT)** explains gas behavior at molecular level.

**Postulates:**
1. Gas particles in constant, random, straight-line motion
2. Particle volume negligible vs. container volume
3. No intermolecular forces (ideal gases)
4. Elastic collisions (no KE loss)
5. Average KE ∝ absolute temperature

**Key Equations:**

**Average Kinetic Energy:**
KE_avg = (3/2)RT per mole
KE_avg = (3/2)kT per molecule
- k = Boltzmann constant = 1.38×10⁻²³ J/K

**Root Mean Square Speed:**
u_rms = √(3RT/M)
- M = molar mass (kg/mol)
- Higher T → faster molecules
- Lighter molecules → faster at same T

Example: At 300K
- H₂ (M = 0.002 kg/mol): u_rms = 1930 m/s
- O₂ (M = 0.032 kg/mol): u_rms = 483 m/s

**Maxwell-Boltzmann Distribution:**
- Range of molecular speeds at given T
- Most probable speed < average speed < rms speed
- Higher T → broader distribution, higher average

**Real Gases:**
Deviate from ideal at:
1. **High P:** Particle volume significant
2. **Low T:** IMF become significant

**Van der Waals Equation:**
(P + an²/V²)(V - nb) = nRT
- a accounts for attractions
- b accounts for particle volume

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Air Quality:** NEA models pollutant dispersion using molecular speeds
- **AC Systems:** HDB air conditioners use gas expansion/compression
- **Petrochemicals:** Jurong Island reactors at high P and T
- **Aviation:** Jet fuel vapor pressure at Changi Airport

sections.title: Phase Changes & Diagrams
sections.content:
**Phase Changes** involve energy changes without temperature change during transition.

**Types:**
1. **Melting/Fusion:** Solid → Liquid (endothermic)
2. **Freezing:** Liquid → Solid (exothermic)
3. **Vaporization:** Liquid → Gas (endothermic)
4. **Condensation:** Gas → Liquid (exothermic)
5. **Sublimation:** Solid → Gas (endothermic)
6. **Deposition:** Gas → Solid (exothermic)

**Energy Calculations:**
- **Heating/Cooling:** q = mcΔT
- **Phase Change:** q = nΔH
  - ΔH_fus (melting)
  - ΔH_vap (boiling)
  - ΔH_sub (sublimation)

**Heating Curve:**
- Flat regions = phase changes (T constant)
- Sloped regions = heating single phase (T increases)

**Phase Diagrams:**
P vs T showing regions where phases exist

**Key Features:**
- **Triple Point:** All 3 phases coexist in equilibrium
- **Critical Point:** Above this, no distinct liquid/gas
- **Normal bp:** Boiling at 1 atm
- **Normal mp:** Melting at 1 atm

**Water (Unusual):**
- Solid/liquid line slopes left (negative)
- Ice less dense than liquid (H-bonding)
- Pressure melts ice (ice skating works!)
- Triple point: 0.01°C, 611 Pa

**Carbon Dioxide:**
- No liquid at 1 atm (sublimes directly)
- Triple point: -57°C, 5.1 atm
- Used for dry ice

**Vapor Pressure:**
- Partial pressure of vapor above liquid
- Increases with temperature
- Boiling: vapor pressure = external pressure
- Volatile: high vapor pressure at room T

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Desalination:** Multi-stage flash evaporation at Tuas
- **Refrigeration:** Phase change cycles in HDB AC units
- **Pharmaceuticals:** Freeze-drying (sublimation) for drug preservation
- **Food Industry:** Dry ice for cold chain logistics
- **Humidity:** High vapor pressure in Singapore's tropical climate

sections.title: Enthalpy Changes
sections.content:
**Enthalpy (H)** is heat content of a system at constant pressure.

**Enthalpy Change (ΔH):**
ΔH = H_products - H_reactants
- **Exothermic:** ΔH < 0 (heat released)
- **Endothermic:** ΔH > 0 (heat absorbed)

**Standard Conditions:**
- 298 K (25°C)
- 100 kPa (1 bar)
- 1 mol dm⁻³ for solutions
- Standard state of elements
- Symbol: ΔH⦵

**Types of Enthalpy Changes:**

**1. ΔH⦵_f (Formation):**
Enthalpy change forming 1 mol compound from elements in standard states
- C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g)     ΔH⦵_f = -394 kJ/mol
- H₂(g) + ½O₂(g) → H₂O(l)    ΔH⦵_f = -286 kJ/mol
- ΔH⦵_f of elements = 0

**2. ΔH⦵_c (Combustion):**
Complete combustion of 1 mol substance in excess O₂
- CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l)   ΔH⦵_c = -890 kJ/mol

**3. ΔH⦵_n (Neutralization):**
Formation of 1 mol H₂O from acid + base
- H⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq) → H₂O(l)   ΔH⦵_n ≈ -57 kJ/mol

**4. ΔH⦵_at (Atomization):**
Forming 1 mol gaseous atoms from element
- Na(s) → Na(g)   ΔH⦵_at = +108 kJ/mol
- ½Cl₂(g) → Cl(g)   ΔH⦵_at = +122 kJ/mol

**5. Bond Dissociation Energy:**
Breaking 1 mol specific bonds in gaseous molecules
- H-H bond: +436 kJ/mol
- C=C bond: +612 kJ/mol

**Singapore Application:**
Singapore's petrochemical industry at Jurong Island:
- Combustion enthalpies determine fuel efficiency
- Reaction enthalpies optimize chemical processes
- Energy management critical for sustainability

sections.title: Hess's Law
sections.content:
**Hess's Law:** Total enthalpy change is independent of route taken (state function).

**Application:** Calculate ΔH for reactions difficult to measure directly

**Method 1: Direct Route**
ΔH_reaction = ΣΔH⦵_f(products) - ΣΔH⦵_f(reactants)

**Example:**
C₂H₄(g) + H₂(g) → C₂H₆(g)

ΔH⦵_f values:
- C₂H₄: +52 kJ/mol
- C₂H₆: -85 kJ/mol
- H₂: 0 kJ/mol

ΔH = (-85) - (52 + 0) = -137 kJ/mol

**Method 2: Combustion Route**
ΔH = ΣΔH⦵_c(reactants) - ΣΔH⦵_c(products)

**Method 3: Energy Cycle**
Draw cycle showing alternative routes:

```
Reactants ----ΔH₁----> Products
    |                      |
   ΔH₂                   ΔH₃
    |                      |
    v                      v
 Intermediate <--ΔH₄--- Elements
```

ΔH₁ = ΔH₂ - ΔH₃

**Bond Enthalpy Calculations:**
ΔH_reaction = Σ(bonds broken) - Σ(bonds formed)
- Breaking bonds: endothermic (+)
- Forming bonds: exothermic (-)

**Example: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O**

Bonds broken:
- 4 × C-H: 4(+413) = +1652 kJ
- 2 × O=O: 2(+498) = +996 kJ
- Total: +2648 kJ

Bonds formed:
- 2 × C=O: 2(-743) = -1486 kJ
- 4 × O-H: 4(-463) = -1852 kJ
- Total: -3338 kJ

ΔH = +2648 + (-3338) = -690 kJ/mol

**Singapore Example:**
Jurong petrochemical plants use Hess's law to:
- Predict reaction energies
- Optimize process conditions
- Calculate heating/cooling requirements
- Design safe chemical processes

sections.title: Born-Haber Cycles
sections.content:
**Born-Haber Cycle** applies Hess's law to ionic compound formation.

**Purpose:** Calculate lattice energy (cannot be measured directly)

**Enthalpy Terms:**

1. **ΔH⦵_f (Formation):** Elements → Compound
2. **ΔH⦵_at (Atomization):** Elements → Gaseous atoms
3. **IE (Ionization Energy):** Gaseous atoms → Cations
4. **EA (Electron Affinity):** Gaseous atoms → Anions
5. **ΔH⦵_L (Lattice Energy):** Gaseous ions → Solid lattice

**Born-Haber Cycle for NaCl:**

```
Na(s) + ½Cl₂(g) --ΔH⦵_f--> NaCl(s)
  |                           ^
  |                           |
 ΔH⦵_at(Na)              -ΔH⦵_L
  |                           |
  v                           |
Na(g)  ½Cl₂(g)                |
  |      |                    |
 IE₁     ΔH⦵_at(Cl)            |
  |      |                    |
  v      v                    |
Na⁺(g)  Cl(g)                 |
  |      |                    |
  |     EA₁                   |
  |      |                    |
  v      v                    |
Na⁺(g) + Cl⁻(g) ------------>|
```

ΔH⦵_f = ΔH⦵_at(Na) + ΔH⦵_at(Cl) + IE₁(Na) + EA₁(Cl) + ΔH⦵_L

**Example Data:**
- ΔH⦵_f(NaCl) = -411 kJ/mol
- ΔH⦵_at(Na) = +108 kJ/mol
- ΔH⦵_at(Cl) = +122 kJ/mol
- IE₁(Na) = +496 kJ/mol
- EA₁(Cl) = -349 kJ/mol

ΔH⦵_L = ΔH⦵_f - (ΔH⦵_at(Na) + ΔH⦵_at(Cl) + IE₁ + EA₁)
ΔH⦵_L = -411 - (108 + 122 + 496 - 349)
ΔH⦵_L = -788 kJ/mol (exothermic)

**Factors Affecting Lattice Energy:**

1. **Charge:** Higher charge → stronger attraction → more negative ΔH⦵_L
   - NaCl: -788 kJ/mol (1+, 1-)
   - MgO: -3791 kJ/mol (2+, 2-)

2. **Ionic Radius:** Smaller ions → closer → stronger attraction
   - LiF > NaF > KF (decreasing ΔH⦵_L magnitude)

**Singapore Application:**
Materials science research at NUS/NTU:
- Designing ionic conductors for batteries
- Optimizing ceramic properties
- Understanding mineral stability
- Developing new materials for electronics

sections.title: Rate Equations
sections.content:
**Reaction Rate** is change in concentration per unit time.

**Rate = -Δ[reactant]/Δt = +Δ[product]/Δt**

**Rate Equation (Rate Law):**
For reaction: aA + bB → products

Rate = k[A]^m[B]^n
- k = rate constant
- m = order with respect to A
- n = order with respect to B
- m + n = overall order

**Important:** Orders (m, n) must be determined experimentally, NOT from stoichiometry!

**Orders of Reaction:**

**Zero Order (m = 0):**
- Rate = k (independent of [A])
- [A] vs t: straight line
- Example: Enzyme-catalyzed at high [substrate]

**First Order (m = 1):**
- Rate = k[A]
- ln[A] vs t: straight line
- Half-life constant: t₁/₂ = ln2/k = 0.693/k

**Second Order (m = 2):**
- Rate = k[A]²  or  Rate = k[A][B]
- 1/[A] vs t: straight line
- Half-life: t₁/₂ = 1/(k[A]₀)

**Determining Orders:**
Initial rates method—change one concentration, hold others constant

**Example:**
2NO(g) + O₂(g) → 2NO₂(g)

| Expt | [NO] | [O₂] | Initial Rate |
|------|------|------|-------------|
| 1 | 0.10 | 0.10 | 2.5×10⁻³ |
| 2 | 0.20 | 0.10 | 1.0×10⁻² |
| 3 | 0.10 | 0.20 | 5.0×10⁻³ |

Doubling [NO]: rate × 4 → order = 2
Doubling [O₂]: rate × 2 → order = 1

Rate = k[NO]²[O₂]
Overall order = 3

**Singapore Application:**
Chemical manufacturing at Jurong Island:
- Optimize reaction conditions
- Scale up from lab to industrial
- Control product quality
- Minimize waste and costs

sections.title: Temperature & Arrhenius Equation
sections.title_zh: 温度与阿伦尼乌斯方程
sections.content:
**Effect of Temperature on Rate:**
Higher temperature → faster reaction (typically doubles per 10K increase)

**Collision Theory:**
For reaction to occur:
1. Molecules must collide
2. With sufficient energy (≥ activation energy, Ea)
3. With correct orientation

**Activation Energy (Ea):**
Minimum energy needed for reaction
- High Ea → slow reaction
- Low Ea → fast reaction

**Arrhenius Equation:**
k = Ae^(-Ea/RT)

- k = rate constant
- A = pre-exponential factor (frequency factor)
- Ea = activation energy (J/mol)
- R = gas constant (8.31 J/(mol·K))
- T = temperature (K)

**Logarithmic Form:**
ln k = ln A - Ea/(RT)

Rearranged:
ln k = -Ea/R × (1/T) + ln A

**Graph of ln k vs 1/T:**
- Straight line
- Slope = -Ea/R
- y-intercept = ln A

**Calculating Ea from Two Temperatures:**
ln(k₂/k₁) = -Ea/R × (1/T₂ - 1/T₁)

**Example:**
At 300K: k₁ = 1.0×10⁻³ s⁻¹
At 310K: k₂ = 2.5×10⁻³ s⁻¹

ln(2.5/1.0) = -Ea/8.31 × (1/310 - 1/300)
ln(2.5) = -Ea/8.31 × (-1.075×10⁻⁴)
0.916 = Ea × 1.29×10⁻⁵
Ea = 71,000 J/mol = 71 kJ/mol

**Maxwell-Boltzmann Distribution:**
- Higher T → more molecules have E ≥ Ea
- Explains exponential temperature dependence

**Singapore Context:**
Singapore's tropical climate (avg 30°C):
- Food spoilage faster than temperate countries
- Refrigeration critical (lower T → slower reactions)
- Chemical storage requires temperature control
- Pharmaceutical stability testing at elevated T

sections.title: Catalysts & Mechanisms
sections.content:
**Catalyst** increases reaction rate without being consumed.

**How Catalysts Work:**
- Provide alternative pathway
- Lower activation energy (Ea)
- More molecules have sufficient energy
- Increases rate constant k

**Important:** Catalyst does NOT change:
- Position of equilibrium
- ΔH of reaction
- Products formed

**Types of Catalysts:**

**1. Homogeneous Catalysis**
Catalyst in same phase as reactants

**Example:** Esterification
CH₃COOH + C₂H₅OH ⇌ CH₃COOC₂H₅ + H₂O
Catalyst: H₂SO₄ (aqueous)

**2. Heterogeneous Catalysis**
Catalyst in different phase (usually solid)

**Example:** Haber Process
N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)
Catalyst: Fe(s)

**Mechanism:**
1. **Adsorption:** Reactants bind to catalyst surface
2. **Reaction:** Bonds break/form on surface
3. **Desorption:** Products leave surface

**Example:** Catalytic converters
2CO + 2NO → 2CO₂ + N₂
Catalyst: Pt/Pd/Rh on ceramic

**Enzymes (Biological Catalysts):**
- Highly specific (lock-and-key)
- Active site binds substrate
- Lower Ea significantly
- Affected by T, pH

**Reaction Mechanisms:**
Step-by-step molecular process

**Elementary Steps:**
- **Unimolecular:** A → products (rate = k[A])
- **Bimolecular:** A + B → products (rate = k[A][B])

**Rate-Determining Step (RDS):**
Slowest step determines overall rate

**Example:**
Overall: 2NO₂ + F₂ → 2NO₂F

Step 1 (slow): NO₂ + F₂ → NO₂F + F
Step 2 (fast): NO₂ + F → NO₂F

Rate = k[NO₂][F₂] (determined by slow step)

**Intermediate:**
- Formed in one step, consumed in another
- Not in overall equation
- Example above: F atom

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Catalytic Converters:** All vehicles in Singapore
- **Petrochemicals:** Jurong Island uses various catalysts
- **Water Treatment:** NEWater uses catalytic processes
- **Green Chemistry:** NUS research on sustainable catalysts
- **Industrial Processes:** Optimization for efficiency

sections.title: Dynamic Equilibrium
sections.content:
**Chemical Equilibrium** is when forward and reverse reaction rates are equal.

**Characteristics:**
1. **Dynamic:** Both reactions continue occurring
2. **Macroscopic properties constant:** Concentrations, pressure, color unchanged
3. **Closed system:** No exchange with surroundings
4. **Can be reached from either direction**

**Reversible Reactions:**
aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD

At equilibrium:
Rate_forward = Rate_reverse

**Equilibrium Constant (Kc):**
Kc = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b

- **Units:** Depend on reaction (mol^n dm^-3n)
- **Temperature dependent:** Different T → different Kc
- **Pure solids/liquids:** Excluded from expression

**Magnitude of Kc:**
- **Kc >> 1:** Equilibrium lies to right (products favored)
- **Kc << 1:** Equilibrium lies to left (reactants favored)
- **Kc ≈ 1:** Significant amounts of both

**Example: Haber Process**
N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)

Kc = [NH₃]² / ([N₂][H₂]³)

At 400°C: Kc = 0.5 (products somewhat favored)
At 500°C: Kc = 0.05 (less favorable—exothermic reversed)

**Equilibrium Constant (Kp):**
For gaseous equilibria, using partial pressures:

Kp = (P_C)^c(P_D)^d / (P_A)^a(P_B)^b

**Relationship:**
Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn
- Δn = (c + d) - (a + b) = change in moles of gas
- R = 0.0821 L·atm/(mol·K)
- T = temperature (K)

**If Δn = 0:** Kp = Kc

**Singapore Context:**
Singapore's chemical industry optimizes equilibria:
- **Ammonia production:** Adjust conditions for maximum yield
- **Petroleum refining:** Cracking reactions at equilibrium
- **Water treatment:** pH equilibria in NEWater processes

sections.title: Le Chatelier's Principle
sections.content:
**Le Chatelier's Principle:** When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts to counteract the change.

**1. Concentration Changes**

**Add reactant:** Equilibrium shifts right (→ more products)
**Remove reactant:** Shifts left (← more reactants)
**Add product:** Shifts left (← more reactants)
**Remove product:** Shifts right (→ more products)

**Example:**
N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)

Add N₂: Shifts right, forms more NH₃
Remove NH₃: Shifts right, forms more NH₃

**Note:** Kc remains constant (only T changes Kc)

**2. Pressure Changes (Gases Only)**

**Increase P (decrease V):**
- Shifts to side with fewer gas molecules
- Reduces pressure by decreasing moles

**Decrease P (increase V):**
- Shifts to side with more gas molecules

**Example:**
N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)
4 moles gas ← → 2 moles gas

Increase P: Shifts right (4 → 2 moles)
Decrease P: Shifts left (2 → 4 moles)

**If equal moles both sides:** No shift

**Adding Inert Gas (constant V):** No shift (partial pressures unchanged)

**3. Temperature Changes**

**Exothermic Reaction:** ΔH < 0 (heat as product)
aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD + heat

- **Increase T:** Shifts left (favors endothermic direction)
- **Decrease T:** Shifts right (favors exothermic direction)
- **Kc changes:** Higher T → smaller Kc for exothermic

**Endothermic Reaction:** ΔH > 0 (heat as reactant)
aA + bB + heat ⇌ cC + dD

- **Increase T:** Shifts right (favors endothermic direction)
- **Decrease T:** Shifts left
- **Kc changes:** Higher T → larger Kc for endothermic

**Example: Haber Process (Exothermic)**
N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)   ΔH = -92 kJ/mol

Industry uses compromise:
- High P (200 atm) favors products
- Moderate T (400-500°C) balances yield and rate
- Fe catalyst increases rate without changing Kc

**4. Catalyst Effect**

**Catalysts:**
- Increase forward AND reverse rates equally
- **NO shift** in equilibrium position
- **NO change** in Kc
- Equilibrium reached **faster**

**Singapore Industrial Applications:**
- **Jurong Island:** Optimizing chemical production
- **Contact Process:** SO₂ + ½O₂ ⇌ SO₃ for sulfuric acid
- **Ammonia Production:** For fertilizers
- **Methanol Synthesis:** CO + 2H₂ ⇌ CH₃OH

sections.title: Equilibrium Calculations
sections.content:
**ICE Table Method** (Initial, Change, Equilibrium)

**Example 1: Calculate Kc**

H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g)

Initial: 1.0 mol H₂, 1.0 mol I₂ in 5.0 L container
Equilibrium: 1.6 mol HI formed

|  | H₂ | I₂ | HI |
|--|----|----|----|
| I | 1.0 | 1.0 | 0 |
| C | -x | -x | +2x |
| E | 1.0-x | 1.0-x | 2x |

2x = 1.6 → x = 0.8

Equilibrium moles:
- H₂: 0.2 mol
- I₂: 0.2 mol
- HI: 1.6 mol

Concentrations (÷5.0 L):
- [H₂] = 0.04 M
- [I₂] = 0.04 M
- [HI] = 0.32 M

Kc = [HI]² / ([H₂][I₂])
Kc = (0.32)² / (0.04)(0.04)
Kc = 64 (no units)

**Example 2: Calculate Equilibrium Concentrations**

N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)   Kc = 0.50 at 400°C

Initial: [N₂] = 1.0 M, [H₂] = 1.0 M, [NH₃] = 0

|  | N₂ | H₂ | NH₃ |
|--|----|----|-----|
| I | 1.0 | 1.0 | 0 |
| C | -x | -3x | +2x |
| E | 1.0-x | 1.0-3x | 2x |

Kc = [NH₃]² / ([N₂][H₂]³)
0.50 = (2x)² / [(1.0-x)(1.0-3x)³]

Solve using approximations or quadratic methods:
x ≈ 0.19 M

Equilibrium:
- [N₂] = 0.81 M
- [H₂] = 0.43 M
- [NH₃] = 0.38 M

**Reaction Quotient (Q):**
Same expression as Kc, but for non-equilibrium concentrations

Q = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b (at any time)

**Predicting Direction:**
- **Q < Kc:** Reaction shifts right (→ products)
- **Q > Kc:** Reaction shifts left (← reactants)
- **Q = Kc:** At equilibrium (no shift)

**Example 3: Kp Calculation**

2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g)

At equilibrium at 1000K:
- P(SO₂) = 0.4 atm
- P(O₂) = 0.2 atm
- P(SO₃) = 0.8 atm

Kp = [P(SO₃)]² / ([P(SO₂)]²[P(O₂)])
Kp = (0.8)² / [(0.4)²(0.2)]
Kp = 0.64 / 0.032
Kp = 20 atm⁻¹

**Convert to Kc:**
Δn = 2 - (2+1) = -1
Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn
20 = Kc(0.0821 × 1000)^(-1)
Kc = 20 × 82.1 = 1642 M

**Singapore Application:**
Chemical engineers at Jurong Island use these calculations to:
- Predict product yields
- Optimize reactor conditions
- Scale from lab to industrial production
- Minimize waste and maximize efficiency

sections.title: Brønsted-Lowry Theory
sections.content:
**Brønsted-Lowry Definition:**
- **Acid:** Proton (H⁺) donor
- **Base:** Proton (H⁺) acceptor

**Conjugate Acid-Base Pairs:**
Differ by one H⁺

**Example:**
HCl(aq) + H₂O(l) → H₃O⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq)

Acid₁   Base₂   Acid₂    Base₁

Pairs:
- HCl/Cl⁻ (conjugate pair)
- H₃O⁺/H₂O (conjugate pair)

**Amphiprotic Species:**
Can act as acid OR base

Examples:
- H₂O: acid (→ OH⁻) or base (→ H₃O⁺)
- HCO₃⁻: acid (→ CO₃²⁻) or base (→ H₂CO₃)
- HSO₄⁻: acid (→ SO₄²⁻) or base (→ H₂SO₄)

**Strong vs. Weak Acids:**

**Strong Acids** (complete dissociation):
- HCl, HBr, HI
- HNO₃, H₂SO₄ (1st proton), HClO₄

**Weak Acids** (partial dissociation):
- CH₃COOH (acetic acid)
- HCOOH (formic acid)
- HF, H₂CO₃, H₃PO₄

**Strong Bases:**
- Group 1 hydroxides: NaOH, KOH
- Group 2 hydroxides: Ca(OH)₂, Ba(OH)₂

**Weak Bases:**
- NH₃ (ammonia)
- Amines: CH₃NH₂
- Conjugate bases of weak acids: CH₃COO⁻

**Water Autoionization:**
H₂O(l) ⇌ H⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq)

Or more accurately:
2H₂O(l) ⇌ H₃O⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq)

**Ionic Product:**
Kw = [H⁺][OH⁻] = 1.0×10⁻¹⁴ at 25°C

**In pure water:**
[H⁺] = [OH⁻] = 1.0×10⁻⁷ M (neutral)

**Acidic:** [H⁺] > [OH⁻]
**Basic:** [H⁺] < [OH⁻]

**Temperature dependence:**
Kw increases with T (endothermic process)

**pH Scale:**
pH = -log[H⁺]
pOH = -log[OH⁻]

pH + pOH = 14 (at 25°C)

**Singapore Context:**
- **NEWater:** pH adjusted for safe drinking (6.5-8.5)
- **Swimming pools:** pH maintained 7.2-7.8 (PUB regulations)
- **Aquariums:** pH critical for tropical fish
- **Industrial processes:** pH monitoring at Jurong Island

sections.title: pH Calculations
sections.content:
**Strong Acid/Base Calculations:**

**Strong Acid:**
[H⁺] = concentration of acid

**Example:** 0.01 M HCl
[H⁺] = 0.01 M = 1.0×10⁻² M
pH = -log(0.01) = 2

**Strong Base:**
[OH⁻] = concentration of base

**Example:** 0.001 M NaOH
[OH⁻] = 0.001 M = 1.0×10⁻³ M
pOH = -log(0.001) = 3
pH = 14 - 3 = 11

**Weak Acid Calculations:**

For HA ⇌ H⁺ + A⁻

Ka = [H⁺][A⁻] / [HA]

**ICE Table:**
|  | HA | H⁺ | A⁻ |
|--|----|----|----|
| I | c | 0 | 0 |
| C | -x | +x | +x |
| E | c-x | x | x |

Ka = x² / (c-x)

**If Ka << c:** Approximation c-x ≈ c
Ka ≈ x²/c
x = √(Ka·c)

**Example:** 0.1 M CH₃COOH, Ka = 1.8×10⁻⁵
x = √(1.8×10⁻⁵ × 0.1) = √(1.8×10⁻⁶) = 1.34×10⁻³
pH = -log(1.34×10⁻³) = 2.87

**Weak Base Calculations:**

For B + H₂O ⇌ BH⁺ + OH⁻

Kb = [BH⁺][OH⁻] / [B]

Similar approach:
[OH⁻] = √(Kb·c)
pOH = -log[OH⁻]
pH = 14 - pOH

**Relationship:**
Ka × Kb = Kw (for conjugate pairs)

pKa + pKb = 14

**Example:** NH₃, Kb = 1.8×10⁻⁵
Conjugate: NH₄⁺
Ka(NH₄⁺) = Kw/Kb = 1.0×10⁻¹⁴ / 1.8×10⁻⁵ = 5.6×10⁻¹⁰

**Salt Hydrolysis:**

**Salt of Strong Acid + Strong Base:**
Neutral (pH = 7)
Example: NaCl

**Salt of Weak Acid + Strong Base:**
Basic (pH > 7)
Example: CH₃COONa
CH₃COO⁻ + H₂O ⇌ CH₃COOH + OH⁻

**Salt of Strong Acid + Weak Base:**
Acidic (pH < 7)
Example: NH₄Cl
NH₄⁺ + H₂O ⇌ NH₃ + H₃O⁺

**Salt of Weak Acid + Weak Base:**
Depends on relative Ka and Kb

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Swimming pools:** Chlorine (HOCl) equilibrium, pH control
- **Water treatment:** Lime (Ca(OH)₂) for pH adjustment
- **Pharmaceuticals:** Drug stability depends on pH
- **Food industry:** Acidity regulators (citric acid, sodium citrate)

sections.title: Buffer Solutions & Titrations
sections.content:
**Buffer Solutions** resist pH change when small amounts of acid/base added.

**Composition:**
1. **Acidic Buffer:** Weak acid + conjugate base (salt)
   - Example: CH₃COOH + CH₃COONa
   - pH < 7

2. **Basic Buffer:** Weak base + conjugate acid (salt)
   - Example: NH₃ + NH₄Cl
   - pH > 7

**Buffer Action:**

**Add H⁺:** Conjugate base neutralizes
A⁻ + H⁺ → HA

**Add OH⁻:** Weak acid neutralizes
HA + OH⁻ → A⁻ + H₂O

**Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation:**

pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA])

or

pH = pKa + log([base]/[acid])

**Example:** Buffer with 0.1 M CH₃COOH and 0.1 M CH₃COONa
Ka = 1.8×10⁻⁵, pKa = -log(1.8×10⁻⁵) = 4.74

pH = 4.74 + log(0.1/0.1) = 4.74 + 0 = 4.74

**Buffer Capacity:**
- Amount of acid/base buffer can neutralize
- Highest when [A⁻] = [HA] (pH = pKa)
- Effective range: pKa ± 1

**Acid-Base Titrations:**

**Strong Acid + Strong Base:**
- pH = 7 at equivalence point
- Sharp vertical region
- Indicators: Any (pH 4-10)

**Weak Acid + Strong Base:**
- pH > 7 at equivalence point (conjugate base)
- Less sharp transition
- Indicators: Phenolphthalein (pH 8.2-10)

**Strong Acid + Weak Base:**
- pH < 7 at equivalence point (conjugate acid)
- Indicators: Methyl orange (pH 3.1-4.4)

**Weak Acid + Weak Base:**
- No sharp endpoint
- Not suitable for titration

**Calculations:**

At equivalence point:
n(acid) = n(base)

MaVa = MbVb (for 1:1 stoichiometry)

**Example:**
25.0 mL HCl titrated with 0.100 M NaOH
23.5 mL NaOH required

Ma × 25.0 = 0.100 × 23.5
Ma = 0.094 M

**Before Equivalence:**
Excess acid remains

**At Equivalence:**
Only salt present

**After Equivalence:**
Excess base present

**Indicators:**
Weak acids that change color with pH
- **Methyl orange:** Red (pH<3.1) → Yellow (pH>4.4)
- **Bromothymol blue:** Yellow (pH<6.0) → Blue (pH>7.6)
- **Phenolphthalein:** Colorless (pH<8.2) → Pink (pH>10)

Choose indicator with range near equivalence pH

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Blood pH:** Natural buffer (H₂CO₃/HCO₃⁻) maintains pH 7.4
- **NEWater:** Buffer systems in treatment
- **Pharmaceuticals:** Buffer formulations for drug stability
- **Environmental:** pH monitoring in reservoirs
- **Laboratory:** Quality control titrations at research institutes
- **Food Industry:** pH control in fermentation processes

sections.title: Oxidation Numbers & Redox
sections.content:
**Oxidation Number (Oxidation State):** Charge atom would have if compound fully ionic.

**Rules for Assigning:**

1. **Free elements:** 0 (O₂, N₂, Fe, Na)
2. **Monatomic ions:** Charge on ion (Na⁺ = +1, Cl⁻ = -1)
3. **Hydrogen:** Usually +1 (except metal hydrides: -1)
4. **Oxygen:** Usually -2 (except peroxides: -1, OF₂: +2)
5. **Fluorine:** Always -1
6. **Group 1:** Always +1
7. **Group 2:** Always +2
8. **Sum of oxidation numbers:**
   - Neutral compound: 0
   - Polyatomic ion: Charge on ion

**Examples:**

**H₂SO₄:**
H: +1 (×2 = +2)
O: -2 (×4 = -8)
S: x
Sum: 2 + x + (-8) = 0 → x = +6

**MnO₄⁻:**
O: -2 (×4 = -8)
Mn: x
Sum: x + (-8) = -1 → x = +7

**Fe₃O₄:**
O: -2 (×4 = -8)
Fe: x (×3)
Sum: 3x + (-8) = 0 → x = +8/3 (fractional—mixed oxidation states)
Actually: Fe²⁺ and Fe³⁺ present

**Redox Reactions:**
Involve electron transfer

**Oxidation:**
- **Loss** of electrons
- **Increase** in oxidation number

**Reduction:**
- **Gain** of electrons
- **Decrease** in oxidation number

**Mnemonic: OIL RIG**
- **O**xidation **I**s **L**oss
- **R**eduction **I**s **G**ain

**Or: LEO says GER**
- **L**ose **E**lectrons **O**xidation
- **G**ain **E**lectrons **R**eduction

**Oxidizing Agent:** Substance that gets reduced (accepts electrons)
**Reducing Agent:** Substance that gets oxidized (donates electrons)

**Example:**
Zn(s) + Cu²⁺(aq) → Zn²⁺(aq) + Cu(s)

Oxidation: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ (Zn: 0 → +2)
- Zn is **reducing agent** (oxidized)

Reduction: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu (Cu: +2 → 0)
- Cu²⁺ is **oxidizing agent** (reduced)

**Types of Redox:**

1. **Combination:** 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO
2. **Decomposition:** 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂
3. **Displacement:** Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu
4. **Disproportionation:** Same element oxidized AND reduced
   - Cl₂ + 2NaOH → NaCl + NaClO + H₂O
   - Cl₂: 0 → -1 (reduction) and 0 → +1 (oxidation)

**Singapore Context:**
- **Corrosion:** Ships at port, MRT infrastructure (Fe → Fe²⁺)
- **Batteries:** Redox reactions power devices
- **Water treatment:** Chlorination (redox disinfection)
- **Electroplating:** Gold plating in jewelry industry

sections.title: Balancing Redox Equations
sections.content:
**Half-Equation Method** (Ion-Electron Method)

**Steps:**

1. **Identify** oxidation and reduction
2. **Write** separate half-equations
3. **Balance** atoms (except O and H)
4. **Balance O** by adding H₂O
5. **Balance H** by adding H⁺ (acidic) or OH⁻ (basic)
6. **Balance charge** by adding electrons
7. **Equalize electrons** in both half-equations
8. **Add** half-equations and cancel common species

**Example 1: Acidic Solution**

MnO₄⁻ + Fe²⁺ → Mn²⁺ + Fe³⁺ (in H⁺)

**Oxidation half:**
Fe²⁺ → Fe³⁺
(atoms balanced)
Fe²⁺ → Fe³⁺ + e⁻ (charge balanced)

**Reduction half:**
MnO₄⁻ → Mn²⁺
(Mn balanced)
MnO₄⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O (O balanced)
MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O (H balanced)
MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O (charge balanced)

**Equalize electrons (×5 for oxidation):**
5Fe²⁺ → 5Fe³⁺ + 5e⁻
MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O

**Add and cancel:**
MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5Fe²⁺ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O + 5Fe³⁺

**Example 2: Basic Solution**

Cr₂O₇²⁻ + I⁻ → Cr³⁺ + I₂ (in OH⁻)

**Step 1-6: Balance as if acidic**

**Reduction:**
Cr₂O₇²⁻ → 2Cr³⁺
Cr₂O₇²⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O
Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O
Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ + 6e⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O

**Oxidation:**
2I⁻ → I₂
2I⁻ → I₂ + 2e⁻

**Equalize (×3 for oxidation):**
6I⁻ → 3I₂ + 6e⁻

**Add:**
Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ + 6I⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O + 3I₂

**Step 7: Convert to basic**
Add OH⁻ equal to H⁺ on both sides:
Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ + 6I⁻ + 14OH⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O + 3I₂ + 14OH⁻

H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O:
Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H₂O + 6I⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O + 3I₂ + 14OH⁻

**Simplify (cancel 7H₂O):**
Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 7H₂O + 6I⁻ → 2Cr³⁺ + 3I₂ + 14OH⁻

**Example 3: Disproportionation**

Cl₂ → Cl⁻ + ClO⁻ (basic)

**Oxidation:** Cl₂ → ClO⁻
Cl₂ → 2ClO⁻
Cl₂ → 2ClO⁻ + 2H₂O
Cl₂ + 4OH⁻ → 2ClO⁻ + 2H₂O
Cl₂ + 4OH⁻ → 2ClO⁻ + 2H₂O + 2e⁻

**Reduction:** Cl₂ → Cl⁻
Cl₂ → 2Cl⁻
Cl₂ + 2e⁻ → 2Cl⁻

**Add:**
2Cl₂ + 4OH⁻ → 2ClO⁻ + 2H₂O + 2Cl⁻

Simplify:
Cl₂ + 2OH⁻ → ClO⁻ + Cl⁻ + H₂O

**Singapore Application:**
Singapore's water treatment uses redox:
- **NEWater:** Ozone (O₃) oxidizes organic contaminants
- **Chlorination:** Cl₂ disproportionation for disinfection
- **UV treatment:** Advanced oxidation processes

sections.title: Electrochemical Cells
sections.content:
**Electrochemical Cells** convert chemical energy to electrical energy (or reverse).

**Types:**

**1. Galvanic (Voltaic) Cells:**
- Spontaneous redox reaction
- Produces electricity
- ΔG < 0, E°cell > 0
- Examples: Batteries, fuel cells

**2. Electrolytic Cells:**
- Non-spontaneous reaction
- Requires external electricity
- ΔG > 0, E°cell < 0
- Examples: Electroplating, electrolysis

**Galvanic Cell Components:**

**Anode:** Oxidation occurs (negative terminal)
**Cathode:** Reduction occurs (positive terminal)

**Salt Bridge:** Maintains electrical neutrality
- Allows ion flow
- Prevents mixing of solutions

**Example: Daniell Cell**
Zn(s) | Zn²⁺(aq) || Cu²⁺(aq) | Cu(s)

**Anode:** Zn(s) → Zn²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻
**Cathode:** Cu²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → Cu(s)
**Overall:** Zn(s) + Cu²⁺(aq) → Zn²⁺(aq) + Cu(s)

**Standard Electrode Potential (E°):**
Voltage of half-cell vs. SHE (Standard Hydrogen Electrode)

**SHE Reference:**
2H⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → H₂(g)   E° = 0.00 V

**Standard Conditions:**
- 298 K
- 1 M solutions
- 1 bar gas pressure

**Cell Potential:**
E°cell = E°cathode - E°anode
E°cell = E°reduction - E°oxidation

**Example:**
Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Zn   E° = -0.76 V
Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu   E° = +0.34 V

For Daniell Cell:
E°cell = E°(Cu²⁺/Cu) - E°(Zn²⁺/Zn)
E°cell = 0.34 - (-0.76) = 1.10 V

**Spontaneity:**
- **E°cell > 0:** Spontaneous (galvanic)
- **E°cell < 0:** Non-spontaneous (requires energy)
- **E°cell = 0:** At equilibrium

**Relationship to ΔG:**
ΔG° = -nFE°cell
- n = moles of electrons
- F = Faraday constant = 96,500 C/mol
- E°cell in volts

**Relationship to K:**
E°cell = (RT/nF) ln K

At 298 K:
E°cell = (0.0592/n) log K

**Nernst Equation:**
Non-standard conditions

E_cell = E°cell - (RT/nF) ln Q

At 298 K:
E_cell = E°cell - (0.0592/n) log Q

Q = [products]^coefficients / [reactants]^coefficients

**Example:**
Zn + Cu²⁺ → Zn²⁺ + Cu
E°cell = 1.10 V, [Zn²⁺] = 0.1 M, [Cu²⁺] = 1.0 M

Q = [Zn²⁺]/[Cu²⁺] = 0.1/1.0 = 0.1

E_cell = 1.10 - (0.0592/2) log(0.1)
E_cell = 1.10 - 0.0296 × (-1)
E_cell = 1.10 + 0.0296 = 1.13 V

**Applications:**

**Batteries:**
- **Zinc-Carbon:** 1.5 V (cheap, disposable)
- **Alkaline:** 1.5 V (longer life)
- **Lithium-ion:** 3.7 V (rechargeable, high density)
- **Lead-Acid:** 2 V per cell, 12 V car battery (6 cells)

**Fuel Cells:**
H₂ + ½O₂ → H₂O
- Clean energy (water byproduct)
- High efficiency (~60%)

**Corrosion:**
Unwanted oxidation
Fe → Fe²⁺ + 2e⁻ (anode)
O₂ + 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ → 2H₂O (cathode)

**Prevention:**
- Protective coatings (paint, plastic)
- Galvanizing (Zn coating—sacrificial anode)
- Cathodic protection (Mg blocks on ships)

**Electrolysis:**
Using electricity to drive non-spontaneous reactions

**Example: Electrolysis of water**
Anode: 2H₂O → O₂ + 4H⁺ + 4e⁻
Cathode: 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ → 2H₂
Overall: 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂

**Faraday's Laws:**
Mass deposited ∝ charge passed
m = (Q × M) / (n × F)
- Q = current × time (coulombs)
- M = molar mass
- n = electrons per ion

**Singapore Applications:**
- **Batteries:** Electric vehicles, smartphones, power banks
- **Fuel Cells:** Research at A*STAR for clean energy
- **Electroplating:** Gold/silver plating in electronics
- **Corrosion Protection:** Ships, MRT rails, pipelines
- **Chlor-alkali Industry:** NaCl electrolysis for NaOH, Cl₂
- **Water Electrolysis:** Hydrogen production for research
